Research article Effectiveness factor for catalyst pellets of non-basic shapes Hong Yong Sohn Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Methodology Funding acquisition Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization a ⁎ Bahador Abolpour Writing – original draft Visualization Validation Software Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation b a Department of Materials Science & Engineering, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, USA Department of Materials Science & Engineering University of Utah Salt Lake City UT USA Department of Materials Science & Engineering, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, USA b Department of Chemical Engineering, Sirjan University of Technology, Sirjan, Kerman, Iran Department of Chemical Engineering Sirjan University of Technology Sirjan Kerman Iran Department of Chemical Engineering, Sirjan University of Technology, Sirjan, Kerman, Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. The shape of a catalyst pellet affects the overall rate of reaction when the reaction is influenced by mass and heat transfer processes. While traditional modeling approaches often assume simple, basic pellet shapes (such as spheres or cylinders), this work focused on the numerical modeling of catalyst pellets with non-basic geometries, which are commonly used in industry. Using numerical techniques, the effectiveness factors of catalyst pellets with various non-basic shapes as functions of the Thiele modulus were investigated. Results indicate that the effectiveness factors of catalyst pellets of non-basic shapes, such as a hollow cylinder, cone, parallelepiped and finite cylinder with hemispherical caps, may be given by a single relationship with a generalized Thiele modulus λp , much as for the cases of basic shapes of a sphere, a long cylinder and a flat slab. This definition of the generalized modulus further provides unified numerical criteria for negligible effects of pore diffusion as λp ≤ 0.3 where E ≈ 1 within ∼10 % error (or λp ≤ 0.1 if an accuracy within ∼1 % is required) and for reaching large λp asymptotic condition as λp ≥ 3 where E ≈ 1 λ p within ∼10 % error (or λp ≥ 10 if an accuracy within ∼1 % is required). Finally, for any shape of the catalyst pellets, the effectiveness factor can be expressed by the following single equation: E = 1 1 + λ p 2 Keywords Catalyst Non-basic shape Effectiveness factor Generalized Thiele modulus Numerical modelling Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. This factor is vital for designing and optimizing catalyst performance, especially in industrial processes that utilize complex shapes of catalyst pellets to maximize surface area and efficiency. Traditionally, simple geometries like spheres and long cylinders have been assumed for the catalyst pellets to estimate the effectiveness factor [1,2]. The calculation of the effectiveness factor for non-basic, irregularly shaped catalyst pellets requires complex solutions or numerical computation [3,4]. Although a first-order reaction is often assumed for the calculation of effectiveness factors, Jayabarathi et al. [5] incorporated the Langmuir–Hinshelwood kinetic equation with a one-dimensional geometry of porous pellets, including spheres, infinite cylinders, and flat pellets. The objective of their work was to utilize efficient and reliable approximate analytical methods to derive semi-analytical expressions for species concentrations and the effectiveness factor. These analytical expressions have facilitated the assessment of the effect of various parameters on species concentrations and the effectiveness factor. Makhania and Upadhyayula [6] developed a heterogeneous foam unit cell model using Body Centered Cubic geometry (BCC) to examine reaction and diffusion processes in foam-based catalysts. They explored kinetic expressions, including general order kinetics and Langmuir–Hinshelwood–Hougen–Watson kinetics, for both isothermal and nonisothermal catalyst wall conditions via finite element method simulations. The authors found that by applying a modified Thiele modulus and using foam diffusion length data, the effectiveness factor versus Thiele modulus relationship resembled the Aris relationship. Additionally, the high thermal conductivity of foam-based catalysts led to minimal temperature gradients, meaning the nonisothermal correction factor had little effect on the effectiveness factor. Wakefield et al. [7] presented a methodology for modeling multi-step reaction rates in porous catalyst particles, intended for use in Computational Fluid Dynamics / Discrete Element Method and two-fluid models. Unlike single-step effectiveness factors based on the Thiele modulus, which were limited in capturing cascading reactions typical in high-temperature vapor-phase reactors (e.g., fluidized catalytic cracking and catalytic biomass pyrolysis), the approach utilized multi-step effectiveness vectors derived from steady-state solutions to reaction–diffusion equations. Solutions for various catalyst shapes, including spheres, cylinders, and prisms, were presented. This paper also addressed computational challenges related to evaluating reaction rates with diffusion limitations and proposed an efficient implementation using pre-computed lookup tables, which was demonstrated through a fluidized bed reactor simulation. Asif [8] highlighted the advantages of using hollow cylindrical catalyst pellets in heterogeneous catalysis for chemical, refinery, and pollution control processes. These pellets improved catalytic material utilization due to the absence of a core, which reduced internal transport resistance and enhanced the effectiveness factor. For first-order irreversible reaction kinetics, varying key shape parameters, such as the ratio of inside to outside radii and the height-to-diameter ratio, significantly increased the effectiveness factor. Higher values of the ratio of inside to outside radii generally enhanced the effectiveness factor, while closer height and diameter dimensions resulted in lower values. Optimizing these parameters led to a better utilization of catalytic material and higher conversion levels. Makhania and Upadhyayula [9] presented a three dimensional model of a foam unit cell, which is depicted using a Body Centered Cubic and Tetrakaidecahedron (TTKD) structural geometries, employing Finite Element Methods to solve the partial differential equations for these structures. The concentration distribution calculated from the simulations is used to determine the diffusion length or shape factor of the foam, aiding in the development of a relationship between effectiveness and the Thiele modulus [10,11]. Asif et al. [12] developed a formula for calculating the effectiveness factor for a catalyst pellet in the shape of a ring. Their results showed that the dimensions of the catalyst pellet play a crucial role in the efficiency of the catalyst, leading to a potential improvement in the effectiveness factor. Mariani et al. [13] investigated how the choice of kinetic equations influences the accuracy of one-dimensional models in predicting the effectiveness factor, with a focus on testing these models on a variety of commercial catalyst pellets. Cho [14] derived an analytical solution to predict the reactant concentration within a porous cylindrical pellet. The effects of the Thiele modulus and the shape of the pellet on the effectiveness factor were examined by determining the mean concentration of reactant at steady state. Cho [15] reported on the modeling of an isothermal first-order reaction in hollow cylindrical pellets. This involved solving the reaction–diffusion equation for a structured catalyst pellet, utilizing analytical solutions. The parameters influencing this factor were examined, with a focus on adjusting the Thiele modulus and geometric characteristics, such as the size of the hollow core and the aspect ratio. Pathak et al. [16] developed a model-based framework aimed at mitigating the impact of model uncertainty on the processes of catalyst identification, design, and optimization. To explore the kinetic parameters, experiments were conducted in a packed bed reactor operating under kinetically controlled conditions. Additionally, the kinetic model was integrated into a two-dimensional model of the catalytic packed bed reactor. This integration was designed to examine the influence of catalyst composition, support material, pellet shapes and sizes, and temperature on the effectiveness factor. Garcia et al. [17] analyzed consecutive reactions in porous catalyst particles, considering both diffusion and chemical reactions, with diffusion limitations affecting both reactants and products. The analysis focused on catalyst particles with non-uniform sizes, specifically those with a log-normal volume particle size distribution (PSD), common in many catalytic applications. When intraparticle diffusion resistances impacted the reactant species, the selectivity to the intermediate product was negatively affected by the dispersion in PSD. A larger spread in PSD led to a more negative impact on selectivity. A methodology for rate analysis, specifically for non-basic geometric solids, was developed by Sohn et al. [18]. This methodology is applicable to solids with shapes of a finite cylinder or a rectangular parallelepiped. It is anticipated that this approach can be extended to accommodate other irregular shapes as well. The process begins by determining an appropriate shape factor under the conditions of a topo-chemical reaction. This factor is subsequently applied to the unified rate expressions that have been previously derived for solids of three basic shapes. The results of this study demonstrate a high degree of agreement between the predicted rates using the appropriate shape factors and the actual or numerical solutions for both reaction-controlled and pore-diffusion-controlled reactions. Sohn and Roy [19] applied the shape factor so obtained to the rate analysis for fluid–solid reactions under mixed control and reported that Sohn's Law of fluid–solid reaction rates [20] produces adequate and effective results when applied together with the non-basic shape-factor approach for calculating the conversion-time relationships. Aris [21] examined the adjustments required for the problem of heat or matter transfer within a bed of spherical particles even when the bed contains particles of irregular shape. It was demonstrated that, the volume to external surface area ratio of an irregularly shaped particle is its characteristic dimension, and the solutions to the steady-state problem of concurrent diffusion and reaction are significantly unaffected by the shape of the particles. The interplay between irreversible, first-order chemical reactions and diffusion was examined by Gunn [22] through the analysis of finite hollow and solid cylinders and theoretical solutions, represented by Fourier-Bessel series. The impact of significant geometric parameters as well as the Thiele modulus on the effectiveness factor was calculated and depicted graphically. Aris [23] and Petersen [24] showed that the effectiveness factors for the three basic shapes can be expressed by the same relationship against the generalized Thiele modulus. In this work, this relationship was extended to catalyst pellets that have several non-basic shapes as used in industry. The objective of the present study was to determine the effectiveness factor for catalyst pellets of various non-basic shapes, as functions of the generalized Thiele parameter, by exact numerical solutions. From the results of the numerical calculation, it was observed that the relationship between the effectiveness factor and the generalized Thiele modulus became approximately the same for all non-basic shapes tested, such as a finite cylinder, a hollow cylinder, a cylinder with hemispherical caps, a cone, and a rectangular parallelepiped. The modeled shapes are depicted in Fig. 1 . 2 Mathematical model 2.1 Catalyst pellets of cylindrical shapes Finite cylinders: Consider a finite cylindrical pellet similar to those modeled by Asif [25] and Ho and Hsiao [26]. The steady-state dimensional and dimensionless concentration profiles of the reactant fluid inside a porous catalyst pellet with an irreversible, first-order reaction are obtained by solving the following partial differential equations: (1) D e r ∂ ∂ r r ∂ C A ∂ r + D e ∂ 2 C A ∂ z 2 = k C A which when normalized becomes (2) 1 η ∂ ∂ η η ∂ ψ ∂ η + ∂ 2 ψ ∂ γ 2 = λ p 2 ψ where ψ = C A C A . S with CA and CA,S being the reactant concentration inside and at the surface of the pellet, respectively; η = r V p / A p is dimensionless coordinate in the radial direction (r); γ = z V p / A p dimensionless coordinate in the axial direction (z); λ p = V p A p k D e is the generalized Thiele modulus; k is the intrinsic reaction rate constant; and De is the effective diffusivity of the fluid in the porous cylindrical catalyst pellet. The volume (Vp ) to surface area (Ap ) ratio of a finite cylinder is (3) V p A p = ξ 1 + 2 ξ R In this equation, (4) ξ = H 2 R is the aspect ratio of the pellet, R is the radius of the cylindrical pellet and H is the length of the cylindrical pellet (Fig. 1). Solving this partial differential equation, with the following boundary conditions, gives the concentration of the reactant fluid at each point within this pellet: (5) at η = η o = R V p / A p = 2 + 1 ξ : ψ = 1 (6) at η = 0 : ∂ ψ ∂ η = 0 (7) at γ = γ o = H / 2 V p / A p = 2 ξ + 1 : ψ = 1 (8) at γ = 0 : ∂ ψ ∂ γ = 0 where η o and γ o are the dimensionless radius and thickness of the catalyst, respectively. The effectiveness factor (E), as a ratio of the reaction rate under the influence of internal diffusion and the rate without it, can be calculated using the concentration profile obtained from the above equations, as follows: (9) E = ∫ 0 γ o ∫ 0 η o η ψ d η d γ ∫ 0 γ o ∫ 0 η o η d η d γ Using the definition of ξ, in this case, (10) E = 2 ξ 1 / ξ + 2 3 ∫ o ( 2 + 1 / ξ ) ξ ∫ 0 2 + 1 / ξ η ψ d η d γ This quantity can also be related to the diffusion rate of the reactant at the external surface of the pellet [26] but for some of the non-basic shapes this latter approach is more complicated. Hollow Cylinders: According to the described method, the volume to surface area ratio of a hollow cylinder is given by (11) V p A p = 1 ξ + 2 1 - δ i - 1 R where (12) δ i = R i R and Ri is the inner radius of the hollow cylinder. The governing equation for reactant concentration, in this case, is similar to Equation (2), with Boundary Condition (6) replaced by the following: (13) at η = η i = R i V p / A p = 1 ξ + 2 1 - δ i δ i : ψ = 1 where η i is the dimensionless inner radius of the catalyst pellet. Equation (9) for the effectiveness factor in this case is modified as follows: (14) E = 2 ξ 1 - δ i 2 [ 1 / ξ + 2 / ( 1 - δ i ) ] 3 ∫ o [ 1 / ξ + 2 / ( 1 - δ i ) ] ξ ∫ [ 1 / ξ + 2 / ( 1 - δ i ) ] δ i 1 / ξ + 2 / ( 1 - δ i ) η ψ d η d γ Finite Cylinders with Hemispherical Caps: The volume to the surface area of a hemisphere-capped cylinder is given by (15) V p A p = 3 ξ + 2 6 ξ + 6 R The governing equation for reactant concentration in a catalyst pellet of this shape and the boundary conditions are also similar to that for finite cylinders, with the boundary conditions at the external surface changed as follows: (16) at γ ≤ γ o = H / 2 V p / A p = 6 ξ + 6 3 ξ + 2 ξ and η = η o = R V p / A p = 6 ξ + 6 3 ξ + 2 : ψ = 1 (17) at γ > γ o = H / 2 V p / A p = 6 ξ + 6 3 ξ + 2 ξ and φ = φ o = R V p / A p = 6 ξ + 6 3 ξ + 2 : ψ = 1 where φ is the dimensionless coordinate in the radial direction of the hemispherical cap ( φ = η 2 + γ - γ o 2 ) and φ 0 is the dimensionless radius of this cap. The effectiveness factor in this case can be obtained by integrating the rate of consumption of the gaseous reactant in the entire pellet and dividing it by the volume of the pellet: (18) E = 2 ( 3 ξ + 2 ) 3 ξ ( 6 ξ + 6 ) 3 ∫ o ξ ( 6 ξ + 6 ) / ( 3 ξ + 2 ) ∫ 0 ( 6 ξ + 6 ) / ( 3 ξ + 2 ) η ψ d η d γ + 3 ( 3 ξ + 2 ) 3 ( 6 ξ + 6 ) 3 ∫ 0 ( 6 ξ + 6 ) / ( 3 ξ + 2 ) φ 2 ψ d φ 2.2 A catalyst pellet of the shape of a cone The volume to surface area ratio of a cone is (19) V p A p = 2 ξ 3 1 + 1 + 4 ξ 2 R The governing equation for reactant concentration in cone-shaped catalyst pellets is the same as that for finite cylinders, except for the boundary conditions given as follows: (20) at η = η o = R 1 - z / H V p / A p = 3 1 + 1 + 4 ξ 2 - γ 2 ξ : ψ = 1 (21) at η = 0 : ∂ ψ ∂ η = 0 (22) at γ = γ o = H V p / A p = 3 1 + 1 + 4 ξ 2 : ψ = 1 (23) at γ = 0 : ψ = 1 The effectiveness factor for this cone-shaped catalyst pellet can also be obtained by performing the integration in Equation (9) using the η o and γ o pertinent to this, as: (24) E = 8 ξ 2 9 1 + 1 + 4 ξ 2 3 ∫ 0 3 + 3 1 + 4 ξ 2 ∫ 0 3 + 3 1 + 4 ξ 2 - γ / 2 ξ η ψ d η d γ 2.3 A catalyst pellet of the shape of a rectangular parallelepiped The dimensionless concentration profile of a reactant fluid inside a porous catalyst pellet with a shape of a rectangular parallelepiped (with dimensions of X/2, Y/2 and Z/2 from the center of symmetry) with a first order reaction is given by the following partial differential equation: (25) D e ∂ 2 C A ∂ x 2 + D e ∂ 2 C A ∂ y 2 + D e ∂ 2 C A ∂ z 2 = k C A which when normalized becomes (26) ∂ 2 ψ ∂ η 2 + ∂ 2 ψ ∂ ρ 2 + ∂ 2 ψ ∂ γ 2 = λ p 2 ψ where η = x V p / A p , ρ = y V p / A p and γ = z V p / A p are dimensionless coordinates in the x, y and z directions, respectively, and (27) V p A p = ξ 1 ξ 2 ξ 1 + ξ 2 + ξ 1 ξ 2 X 2 where ξ 1 = Y X and ξ 2 = Z X are aspect ratios of the pellet. Solving this equation with the following boundary conditions gives the concentration of the fluid reactant at any point within the pellet: (28) at η = η o = X / 2 V p / A p = 1 ξ 1 + 1 ξ 2 + 1 : ψ = 1 (29) at η = 0 : ∂ ψ ∂ η = 0 (30) at ρ = ρ o = Y / 2 V p / A p = ( 1 ξ 1 + 1 ξ 2 + 1 ) ξ 1 : ψ = 1 (31) at ρ = 0 : ∂ ψ ∂ ρ = 0 (32) at γ = γ o = Z / 2 V p / A p = ( 1 ξ 1 + 1 ξ 2 + 1 ) ξ 2 : ψ = 1 (33) at γ = 0 : ∂ ψ ∂ γ = 0 Here, η o , ρ o and γ o indicate the dimensionless thicknesses of this catalyst. The effectiveness factor for this pellet is given by (34) E = ∫ 0 γ o ∫ 0 ρ o ∫ 0 η o ψ d η d ρ d γ γ o ρ o η o Substituting relevant dimensionless characters in this equation gives (35) E = ∫ 0 ( 1 / ξ 1 + 1 / ξ 2 + 1 ) ξ 2 ∫ 0 ( 1 / ξ 1 + 1 / ξ 2 + 1 ) ξ 1 ∫ 0 1 / ξ 1 + 1 / ξ 2 + 1 ψ d η d ρ d γ ξ 1 ξ 2 1 / ξ 1 + 1 / ξ 2 + 1 3 2.4 Large Thiele modulus asymptote Previous authors [27] have shown a derivation of the reaction rate as λp approaches infinity where the reaction is essentially completed within a thin layer near the external surface of the catalyst pellet. Thus, the actual reaction rate can be expressed per unit external surface, regardless of pellet shape. Under this asymptotic condition, the reactant concentration in the porous catalyst pellet can be described by the following: (36) D e d 2 C A d x 2 = k C A which when normalized becomes (37) d 2 ψ d ϛ 2 = λ p 2 ψ where ϛ = x V p / A p is a normalized distance from the surface into the pellet interior. The appropriate boundary conditions are (38) at ϛ = 0 : ψ = 1 (39) at ϛ → ∞ : ψ = 0 and d ψ d ϛ = 0 From the solution of the above governing equation with the boundary conditions, we obtain the effectiveness factor for large λp as follow: (40) E = 1 λ p This relationship applies regardless of the pellet geometry and thus the numerical solutions presented below should also approach this condition as λp increases toward infinity. 2.5 The effect of external mass transfer on large Thiele modulus asymptote The effect of external mass transfer on effectiveness factor can be incorporated by replacing ψ in Equation (37) by ϕ = C A C A . b , where CA,b is the reactant concentration in the bulk fluid, and Boundary Condition (38) by: (41) at ϛ = 0 : - d ϕ d ϛ = λ p 2 σ 1 - ϕ where (42) σ = k k m V p A p From the solution of the above governing equation with the boundary conditions, we obtain (43) E = 1 λ p + σ = 1 λ p 1 + k D e k m for large λp including the effect of external mass transfer (km ). 3 Numerical method Based on the finite difference approach, the discretized format of Equation (37) utilizing the finite difference method for meshed catalyst pellet (with i indexes for ϛ direction) is: (44) ψ i = ψ i + 1 + ψ i - 1 Δ ϛ 2 · 2 Δ ϛ 2 + λ p 2 - 1 In this study, the two- and three-dimensional discretized equations have been solved in the defined meshes for these geometries, with up to 1000 calculation nodes in each direction, which is chosen after grid study. The convergence of the calculations was accepted when the residual error reaches 10-6. After this convergence, the obtained dimensionless concentration profiles were used to calculate the effectiveness factor using the discretized formats of the relevant integral equations. The effectiveness factor can be calculated using the following equation, numerically: (45) E = ∑ ψ Δ ϛ i ∑ Δ ϛ i One of the most important aspects of the presented numerical method for calculating the effectiveness factor is that it is possible to consider a non-first-order dependency of the reaction rate on the reactant concentration, which cannot in general be solved analytically [28]. For example, for nth -order reactions in a catalyst pellet within the large Thiele modulus asymptote, the dimensional governing equation is: (46) D e d 2 C A d x 2 = k C A n Using dimensionless variables ψ = C A C A . S and ϛ = x V p / A p , the normalized form of this equation is (47) d 2 ψ d ϛ 2 = λ p 2 C As n - 1 ψ n = λ p . n 2 2 n + 1 ψ n with x defined as the direction into the solid from the surface. The boundary conditions for this case, with the fast external mass transfer condition, are similar to Boundary Conditions (38) and (39). The discretized format of Equation (47) is given by: (48) ψ i = ψ i + 1 + ψ i - 1 Δ ϛ 2 · 2 Δ ϛ 2 + 2 n + 1 λ p . n 2 ψ i n - 1 - 1 where (49) λ p . n = λ p n + 1 2 C As n - 1 It should be noted that using this definition of λ p . n at the asymptotic conditions, we have: (50) E = A p - D e d C A / d x x = 0 V p k C As n = 1 λ p . n 4 Results and Discussion 4.1 Validation with finite cylinders Fig. 2 shows a comparison among the calculated E for a finite cylindrical catalyst pellet with ξ = 1 using the present numerical method and the exact values of E for sphere, cylinder and flat plate by Petersen [27] and Knozinger and Weitkamp [29], among others, as functions of λp . It is seen that the result for a catalyst pellet of a finite cylindrical shape lies closely with the exact values for the three basic shapes, which themselves are very close to each other. Also shown in this figure is the curve for the following equation: (51) E = 1 1 + λ p 2 which represents these lines quite satisfactorily. The idea for testing this equation originated from the analysis of a fluid–solid reaction taking place in an initially porous solid [30], although it may just be considered a correlation equation. Fig. 3 illustrates the independency of the calculated E values from the geometry of the catalyst pellet for the entire range of λp . Fig. 4 reveals the calculated values of E for different orders of irreversible reaction rates in cylindrical catalyst pellets with ξ = 1 as a function of a modified Thiele modulus defined in Equation (49). The calculated values of the effectiveness factor for this type of catalyst pellets with λp = 1000 is 9.687 × 10-4 using Equation (9). It agrees with the large Thiele modulus asymptote that E = 1 λ p . 4.2 Effectiveness factor for catalysts of other non-basic shapes The numerically calculated effectiveness factors for catalyst pellets of the shape of a hollow cylinder with varying ξ and ηi as functions of λp are presented in Fig. 5 . This analysis confirms that the calculated E values for the catalyst pellets of this shape essentially lie on the same line as functions of λp . Similarly, Fig. 6 depicts the calculated E for hemisphere-capped cylindrical catalyst pellets with different ξ values as functions of λp , further validating the independence of the calculated E values from the geometry of the catalyst pellet of this shape over various λp . Fig. 7 presents the calculated E for cone-shaped catalyst pellets with differing ξ values as functions of λp , reinforcing the notion that the calculated E values are independent of these geometries across a range of λp . Additionally, Fig. 8 illustrates the calculated effectiveness factors for various geometries of rectangular parallelepiped catalytic pellets as functions of the generalized Thiele modulus. As anticipated, all curves presented in these figures align with the findings of Petersen [27] and Knozinger and Weitkamp [29], thereby affirming the independence of these curves from the geometries of the catalyst pellets. 5 Concluding Remarks The present study applied a numerical method to determine the effectiveness factors of catalyst pellets with non-basic geometries, such as hollow cylinders, hemisphere-capped cylinders, cones, and rectangular parallelepipeds, as functions of the generalized Thiele modulus. The numerical results clearly demonstrate that the effectiveness factor, when expressed as a function of the generalized Thiele modulus (defined by volume and external surface area), is largely independent of the pellet geometry and becomes identical for all shapes. This approach was validated through comparisons between numerical results and analytical solutions for catalyst pellets with cylindrical, spherical, and flat plate shapes. Thus, the generalized Thiele modulus provides a robust parameter for predicting catalyst performance across a wide range of geometries and reaction conditions, without the need for geometry-specific corrections. Furthermore, this definition of the modulus provides unified numerical criteria for negligible effects of pore diffusion as λp ≤ 0.3 where E ≈ 1 within ∼10 % error (or λp ≤ 0.1 if an accuracy within ∼1 % is required) and for reaching large λp asymptotic condition as λp ≥ 3 where E ≈ 1 λ p within ∼10 % error (or λp ≥ 10 if an accuracy within ∼1 % is required). Finally, for any shapes of the catalyst pellets, the effectiveness factor can be expressed by the following single equation: E = 1 1 + λ p 2 These findings have significant implications for the design and optimization of industrial catalyst pellets, as they suggest that the same performance criteria can be applied to catalyst pellets of any shapes, simplifying the analysis and development of catalytic systems. Future work could extend this method to more complex reaction kinetics or explore its application to multicomponent systems, further broadening its utility in industrial catalytic processes. coredata.dc:description: The shape of a catalyst pellet affects the overall rate of reaction when the reaction is influenced by mass and heat transfer processes. While traditional modeling approaches often assume simple, basic pellet shapes (such as spheres or cylinders), this work focused on the numerical modeling of catalyst pellets with non-basic geometries, which are commonly used in industry. Using numerical techniques, the effectiveness factors of catalyst pellets with various non-basic shapes as functions of the Thiele modulus were investigated. Results indicate that the effectiveness factors of catalyst pellets of non-basic shapes, such as a hollow cylinder, cone, parallelepiped and finite cylinder with hemispherical caps, may be given by a single relationship with a generalized Thiele modulus λp , much as for the cases of basic shapes of a sphere, a long cylinder and a flat slab. This definition of the generalized modulus further provides unified numerical criteria for negligible effects of pore diffusion as λp ≤ 0.3 where E ≈ 1 within ∼10 % error (or λp ≤ 0.1 if an accuracy within ∼1 % is required) and for reaching large λp asymptotic condition as λp ≥ 3 where E ≈ 1 λ p within ∼10 % error (or λp ≥ 10 if an accuracy within ∼1 % is required). Finally, for any shape of the catalyst pellets, the effectiveness factor can be expressed by the following single equation: E = 1 1 + λ p 2
